HEADLINE: This Week in Small Business: Firing the Founder

BYLINE: GENE MARKS


HIGHLIGHT: Google spawns start-ups in Kansas City &#8212; and also reinvents human resources. Why using social media well is harder than you think. Ten ideas for marketing and advertising. And do you think it&#8217;s harder to run a business today than it was five years ago? 

 BODY:
What's affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.
 Must-Reads 
Google Fiber spawns a start-up renaissance in Kansas City. Floyd Norris explains how a brilliant tax-avoidance strategy for S corporations went terribly wrong. And Scott Horsley believes rock 'n' roll explains the economy.
 Economy: Still Grumpy
Builder confidence reaches its highest level since 2006, and the Architecture Billings Index rebounds strongly. Housing starts were up 6.8 percent in May, but Steven Hansen's analysis paints a slightly different picture. Manufacturing conditions in the New York (pdf) and Philadelphia regions improved, household financial health is looking up, and people are spending more on weddings. Dun & Bradstreet advises that: "While the outlook is brighter, it's important to understand this recovery remains uneven depending on geography, vertical and individual company health." Key measures also show low and falling inflation, and a prominent economist is now predicting growth to be 3 to 3.5 percent. But the number of Standard & Poor's 500 companies that have issued earnings guidance below consensus analyst estimates is running higher than normal. And Harvard's Niall Ferguson is still grumpy. 
 The Fed: Stepping Off the Gas 
Ben S. Bernanke prepares to step off the gas, and Wall Street throws a tantrum. Justin Wolfers helps explain what the Federal Reserve is saying. Eduardo Porter makes the case for a rise in inflation, and Matthew Yglesias believes that with inflation low, the Fed should stay far away from tighter money. This chart shows how bad the Fed is at predicting the future, and these three charts show that the recent stock market rally is not all about the Fed.
 Management: Firing the Founder 
Mike Martel explains why you should not "eat the elephant" one bite at a time: "The real problem with taking it step by step is that most people lose interest and end up quitting." This is how an old barn and a cider press became a thriving small business and a local institution. Rafi Mohammed explains how Microsoft "blew it" on the price of Xbox One. Here are 10 books every entrepreneur should read. Michael Dillon thinks franchisees should take it upon themselves to make changes. The founder of Men's Wearhouse is fired (it's tricky when the founder is also the face of the brand). Here are seven reasons you need a business plan. Maria Konnikova demonstrates how caffeine can cramp your creativity, and another report finds that dim lighting sparks it. Were these small businesses misledby a credit service's sales pitch?
 Small Business Week: It's Getting Harder 
President Obama proclaimed last week National Small Business Week. The Latino Coalition, Citizens Bank, the National Association of Small Business Professionals, Chrysler, and Google all sent their regards. The Small Business Administration celebrated its champions in Illinois, and Ernst & Young used the occasion to name its American and worldwide Entrepreneurs of the Year. Brock Blake thinks a Micro Business Week might be more appropriate. A survey from Capital One Bank says small-business conditions are improving, and another from Citibank reveals a three-year high in how owners view business conditions. However, almost half of small-business owners say access to credit is still a problem. A Constant Contact survey finds that the majority of small businesses say it's harder to run a business today than five years ago, and this infographic explains how running a start-up has changed. But have faith: a UPS Store survey finds that 48 percent of Americans dream of starting a business, while 71 percent of small-business owners say they would start their businesses all over again.
 People: Reinventing H.R. 
Here's how Google is reinventing human resources - but the company acknowledges its infamous brainteasers were completely useless for hiring, and a former Google and Microsoft engineer explains why he would have hired Edward Snowden: "elitist, arrogant rebels often make the best employees." A 30-year-old explains why he took an internship. There's much to be learned from the best employers for baby boomers. Bob Phibbs has suggestions for empowering employees. This is how eight retail workers make the most of their free time. Data show that people joining the work force today are less educated than those leaving it. Two Dunkin' Donuts employees get rave reviews for handling a racist rant. ADP says the number of franchise jobs grew by 19,160 in May, and surprise: an analysis says that the more applications you fill out, the better chance you have of getting a job. Shawn Stefani hits a hole-in-one at Merion.
 Entrepreneurs: Learn to Code 
Steve Mariotti interviews Maria Jimenez, a top youth entrepreneurship educator. Kylie Toh believes all entrepreneurs should learn to code because it enables you to be self-sufficient. The House Committee on Small Business highlights a few "made in the U.S.A." stories of small manufacturers. Entrepreneurs are impressive, but not as impressive as these new astronauts. A social media app from Deluxe uncovers the secret identities of America's small-business owners.
 Social Media: Harder Than You Think 
Here are a few creative ways to use Pinterest for your business. Barbara Findlay Schenck has nine tips to power up your social media. Chris Marentis warns that effective social media marketing is more difficult than most people think. Facebook passes one million advertisers and brings video to Instagram. Tom Andel shares stories of manufacturers succeeding by using social media. A satirical Taylor Swift Twitter feed gains 80,000 followers in six days. This is how a two-star Amazon review makes thousands of sales. This infographic shows why going viral online is big business. A webinar will help you measure and improve your internal e-mail.
 Sales and Marketing: Dueling E-Mail Services 
Giancarlo Massaro shares advice for how to get leads and sales. Here are 34 research reports on content marketing. SendGrid picks an e-mail marketing fight with MailChimp. These were the top 10 ideas from marketing and advertising over the last 12 months. This is how to offer smarter customer support on the go. Scott Anthony explains what 10-foot noodles have to do with competitive advantage.
 Around the Country: Free Power 
In New York, a restaurant abolishes tips, residents get free power-charging stations, and apartment dwellers may have to start collecting food scraps for composting. Delta and JetBlue lead airline service rankings (and this hedgehog leads an adventurous life). The Congressional Budget Office estimates that the Senate's immigration bill would reduce the deficit by $197 billion over 10 years. An Entrepreneur Center opens near Nashville.
 Around the World: Giant Balloons 
Joe Weisenthal thinks it's hard to look at these photos from Indonesia and Brazil "and not worry about a much bigger emerging market blow-up." British students get fooled by a "Star Wars" prank. Diana Ransom explains what it takes to start up in Turkey after the recent protests. China's factory activity hits a nine-month low, job prospects for China's grads are getting bleaker and a credit bureau says China's credit bubble is unprecedented in modern world history (but that'snot deterring General Motors from investing $11 billion there). Google's plans to beam the Internet from giant balloons sent to the stratosphere could help small businesses in rural parts of Asia.
 Ideas: Better Air 
A Zipcar-style service for airplanes is introduced. A teenage scientist designs a sustainable and cost-effective biofilter to remove chemical pollutants from indoor air streams. Here's how to add the integers from 1 to N quickly.
 Technology: Bug Bounties 
General Electric is hiring thousands of engineers to build an "industrial Web." Here are three cloud-based surveillance options that will help keep an eye on your business. A survey finds many small businesses are in the dark about the potential impact of a data breach. With "bug bounties," Microsoft extends an olive branch to the hacker community. Two of the biggest names in 3-D printing merge. Erica Ogg reports that everybody loves the new MacBook Air's battery. A search engine alternative to Google hits 3.1 million queries. Google, Office 365 and Dropbox lead in cloud growth.
 Tweet of the Week 
@danmartell - Free advice is often overpriced.
 The Week's Best Quotes 
 Margie Warrell says you should take the risk because the odds are better than you think: "We are neurologically wired to exaggerate how bad things could be if our plans didn't work out, and we fail to appreciate our ability to intervene to ward off further impact."
 Andrew Dowling explains why parents make better entrepreneurs: "Anyone launching themselves into a new business quickly finds they're dealing with lots of things which are unfamiliar to them. From the moment you discover you're going to become a parent, your trajectory is remarkably similar. Your life suddenly changes in a big way forever. You find yourself dealing with concepts and terminology you've never had an interest in before. And once your kids are born, you'd better get used to dealing with change, because that's what your life is going to consist of for the next couple of decades."
 This Week's Question: Do you think it's harder to run a business today than it was five years ago?
 Gene Marks owns the Marks Group , a Bala Cynwyd, Pa., consulting firm that helps clients with customer relationship management. You can follow him on Twitter.

LENGTH: 1444 words

HEADLINE: Mass Layoffs at a Top-Flight Law Firm

BYLINE: PETER LATTMAN


HIGHLIGHT: The prestigious law firm Weil, Gotshal &#038; Manges is laying off a large number of lawyers and support staff, as well as reducing the pay of some partners, a move that underscores the difficulties facing the legal profession. 

 BODY:
Layoffs are a brutal reality of corporate America. During fallow periods, publicly traded companies, including the big banks, routinely cull their ranks. The country's largest law firms, by contrast, have historically taken a kinder, gentler approach, rarely firing employees en masse.
The news on Monday that Weil, Gotshal & Manges, among the nation's most prestigious and profitable law firms, was laying off a large number of lawyers and support staff while also reducing the pay of some of its partners, sent shock waves through the industry and underscored the financial difficulties facing the legal profession.
 Sixty junior lawyers, known at firms as associates, lost their jobs. That amounts to roughly 7 percent of Weil's associates. Annual compensation will be reduced for roughly 30 of the firm's 300 partners, in many cases by hundreds of thousands of dollars. And 110 non-lawyers - roughly half of them secretaries - were let go.
The leadership of Weil, a New York-based firm of 1,200 lawyers that counts General Electric and Sanofi as marquee clients and handled the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers, informed its employees Monday morning about the reductions. 
"While we have been able to avoid these actions in the past, and it is very painful from a human perspective, the management committee believes that these actions are essential now to enable our firm to continue to excel and retain its historic profitability in the new normal," Barry M. Wolf, Weil's executive partner, wrote in a firmwide e-mail.
The "new normal," in the view of Weil's management and echoed by legal industry experts, is that the market for high-end legal services is continuing to shrink. Dan DiPietro, chairman of the law firm group at Citi Private Bank, said he believed that the profession could experience a wave of job cuts. He said that there were too many lawyers at the country's largest firms, estimating the excess capacity at as much as 10 percent of the lawyer population.
"My guess is that a good number of firms have been thinking about right-sizing and waiting for someone to provide them cover and we'll see more of these moves," Mr. DiPietro said. "As difficult as layoffs are, it seems that they will be necessary for some firms to get in sync with the current market dynamics."
Those market dynamics have shifted starkly from the boom years leading up to the financial crisis. Pre-2008, profitability exploded and the number of lawyers grew at the country's top firms as demand increased about 4 percent a year. But demand has been flat to down for the last five years, according to several industry reports, and shows little sign of picking up.
At Weil, whose partners make, on average, about $2.2 million a year, the situation is unique. During the depths of the downturn, the firm avoided the layoffs that some other firms were forced to make. That was largely because of the firm's pre-eminent bankruptcy practice, which advised both General Motors and Lehman on their Chapter 11 filings. Those assignments, particularly Lehman, generated hundreds of millions of dollars in fees, not only in bankruptcy work, but also from the reams of litigation that flowed from them.
In an interview last week, Mr. Wolf said that Weil's leaders thought that as the crisis-related assignments wound down and the economy recovered, the firm would see a pickup in its "transactional business," the lucrative work of advising corporations and private equity firms on acquisitions, as well as performing legal work for stock and bond offerings. But transactional activity at Weil remains soft and has not returned to anywhere near pre-2008 levels.
Nevertheless, the firm has performed well relative to its peers, according to data compiled by Bloomberg and Thomson Reuters. In 2012, Weil was ranked No. 1 in private equity representations globally. It ranked No. 2 in domestic mergers and acquisitions last year and has maintained that position in 2013, advising on deals like the American Airlines merger with US Airways. Still, Mr. Wolf said, there was not enough work to keep Weil's army of lawyers sufficiently busy.
"Our market share has been improving, but the market has been shrinking," Mr. Wolf said.
Mr. Wolf, a corporate lawyer who joined Weil in 1984 straight out of law school, said that while the decision to cut associates and staff was personally distressing for him and the management committee, there was little disagreement that it was the right one.
"We believe that this not just a cycle but that the supply-demand balance is out of whack across the industry," he said. "If we thought this was a cycle and our business was going to pick up meaningfully next year, we would not be doing this."
Monday was a grim day at Weil, with partners informing associates of their dismissals in one-on-one meetings. Each gets six months of severance. Partners subject to salary reductions have already been informed by firm management. (There are no partner cuts because under Weil's partnership agreement, partners can be fired only for cause.)
The mass layoffs are the first in the 82-year history of Weil, which has 21 offices worldwide and headquarters in the General Motors building, one of New York's most coveted business addresses. Last year, the firm posted revenue of about $1.2 billion, and its profits per partner ranked 17th of all firms nationally.
In Monday's e-mail, Weil said it was taking the action "from a position of strength." It said that it had zero debt and a fully financed pension plan with more than $500 million in assets. It also noted that its partners did not have long-term compensation guarantees.
By listing those attributes, Weil appeared to be pre-emptively addressing comparisons to Dewey & LeBoeuf, a firm of a similar size that dissolved last year. Dewey collapsed after disappointing profits and a heavy debt load forced it to slash partners' salaries. Many Dewey partners had multiyear, multimillion-dollar contracts. When they did not get paid their guarantee, they fled, crippling the firm.
Now, a year after Dewey's demise, most industry specialists view the firm as an outlier, a victim of gross financial mismanagement. Still, some of Dewey's problems partly derived from the same industry trends facing successful firms like Weil.
Among the main factors hurting law firm profitability is that corporate clients have become stingy. Until recently, pricing pressure barely existed for premium legal services. Decades ago, clients would receive a bill with only a lump sum and the statement "for professional services rendered."
But today, big corporations, facing pressures of their own, have clamped down on legal expenses. They have beefed up their in-house legal staffs and perform much of the work themselves. They are demanding that for routine assignments like document discovery, work be sent to outsourcing firms and contract lawyers rather than given to expensive associates. And they ask for discounts or capped fees at places like Weil, which charge more than $1,000 an hour for some partners' work.
Steven J. Harper, a retired partner at Kirkland & Ellis and author of "The Lawyer Bubble: A Profession in Crisis" (Basic Books, 2013), said that Weil's move highlighted the inexorable long-term trend: big firm partnerships were now nothing more than bottom-line, profit-maximizing businesses.
Profits per partner - a statistic highlighted annually in the closely watched American Lawyer magazine rankings - have become an unhealthy obsession, Mr. Harper said. Driving this fixation is the frenzied lateral hiring market, in which firms are poaching lawyers with big books of business from rivals. Firms fear that if profitability wanes, they will lose their stars.
"The culture at most of these large law firms is that you must maintain astronomical levels of partner earnings in order to keep your top talent," Mr. Harper said. "Cutting staff is one way to do that."
Mr. Wolf of Weil said that while layoffs would help the firm's profits, the move was not motivated by reducing expenses to enrich partners.
"This is not about cost-cutting but about the future of the firm and strategically positioning us for the next five years," Mr. Wolf said.
Several industry experts applauded the move. Peter Zeughauser, a law firm consultant, said that many firms were in denial about slack demand, and Weil's cutbacks could pressure them into getting leaner.
"We have been telling our clients about these economic realities for some time," Mr. Zeughauser said. "Weil is a bellwether firm, and this will be a real wake-up call."

LENGTH: 6493 words

HEADLINE: Live Analysis of Supreme Court Decision on Affirmative Action

BYLINE: THE NEW YORK TIMES


HIGHLIGHT: The Supreme Court ruled on Thursday on Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin, a case concerning affirmative action. Times reporters and editors are analyzing the decision and its implications, as well as the public&#8217;s reaction to it. 

 BODY:
 The Supreme Court ruled Monday that lower courts did not apply a sufficiently high level of scrutiny to the University of Texas' use of race in admissions decisions, sending the case back to one of those lower courts to be reconsidered.
 3:39 P.M. | Four Takeaways From the Affirmative-Action Decision 
The Supreme Court did not reject the University of Texas at Austin's affirmative-action program on Monday, but it did ask a lower court to take a newly tough look at it. Adam Liptak, our Supreme Court correspondent, called the decision "simultaneously modest and significant" and said it was "likely to give rise to a wave of challenges to admissions programs at colleges and universities nationwide."
As part of The New York Times's coverage of the case, Fisher v. University of Texas, we posed four questions to several experts, of varying views, to analyze the decision. You can read the full answers on our blog, but here are four takeaways from their answers: 
1.The ruling was a surprise. Most court watchers expected a narrow, five-member majority, with Justice Anthony Kennedy writing a decision that the four other conservative-leaning justices joined. "We were not expecting a 7-1 vote," said Ada Meloy, general counsel at the American Council on Education, which represents college and university presidents. Only Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg dissented (and Justice Elena Kagan recused herself because of her prior involvement in the case as an Obama administration lawyer).
"What's remarkable is how broad a coalition agreed to handle the case in this moderate way," said Richard A. Primus, a law professor at the University of Michigan. Liberals can take comfort that the court did nothing to alter affirmative action immediately. Conservatives can take comfort that the justices held that courts were not currently applying sufficiently tough scrutiny to affirmative-action programs.
2.The court appears to have effectively raised the legal bar for affirmative-action programs in future cases. The justices held that colleges and universities were now too quick to used race-based admissions programs without searching for other ways to build diverse classes. In the process, colleges and universities may be violating the court's prior ruling that any programs based on race must pass a legal test known as strict scrutiny.
"When an affirmative action plan gets challenged in court, the court must be satisfied that there are 'no workable race-neutral alternatives' to achieve the educational benefits of diversity," Sheryll Cashin, a former Supreme Court clerk who is now a professor at Georgetown University, wrote.
The fact that two liberal justices, Stephen Breyer and Sonia Sotomayor, were willing to sign on to such a decision was one of the more surprising aspects of the ruling, said Richard D. Kahlenberg of the Century Foundation.
3.The most obvious alternatives to race-based affirmative action revolve around economic class. In such programs, universities would give students credit for coming from a more disadvantaged background - taking into account not just income, as many colleges now claim they do, but also potentially wealth, neighborhood and single-parent status. Such programs would almost certainly pass constitutional muster and would help many black and Latino applicants, but class-based programs are also more expensive than race-based programs, many of which result in predominantly wealthy student bodies.
"The new higher standard is likely to discourage universities from using race and opening themselves up to litigation," said Mr. Kahlenberg, an advocate of class-based affirmative action. "If that occurs, the decision will be a boon to low-income and working-class students of all racial backgrounds who have to date been effectively shut out of selective colleges."
4. Justice Kennedy has changed his argument over the last decade. In the 2003 Grutter case, which upheld the University of Michigan's affirmative-action program, he wrote an aggressive dissent. It is hard to square Texas's affirmative-action program with that dissent, but his majority decision in Fisher did not throw out the Texas program.
"Justice Kennedy seems to have made his peace with Grutter in part by putting his gloss on it," Ms. Cashin wrote. "He is very comfortable with the idea that universities have a compelling interest in the educational benefits of diversity. He reaffirmed that they even deserve deference on why diversity produces educational benefits. He made it clear, however, that any use of race must be narrowly tailored and that judges, not universities, get to decide what narrow tailoring means."
- David Leonhardt 
 3:12 P.M. | Fisher, U.T. Austin Respond to Court's Ruling 
Abigail Fisher, the young woman who sued the University of Texas over its affirmative action policy after she was denied admission, spoke briefly at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington on Monday.
"I am grateful to the justices," Ms. Fisher said, for the 7-to-1 decision sending the case back to the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration under a tougher standard of review. "I'm just very honored and grateful to have participated in this," she said. "I am very confident U.T. won't be able to use race as a factor in admissions in the future."
At a news conference, she stood with her parents, Richard and Rosalie Fisher, and Edward Blum, the man who has been the driving force behind the case. Though he is not a lawyer, he bankrolls litigation that pursues conservative ends through his Project on Fair Representation.
Mr. Blum said the decision "begins the restoration of the original colorblind principles to our nation's civil rights laws," and would hasten the end of racial preferences in schools across the nation. Of the court's requirement that racial distinctions in admissions be subject to strict scrutiny, he said, "It is very unlikely that most institutions will be able to overcome these hurdles."
Some groups favoring affirmative action claimed at least a partial victory because the court left the Texas program in place. Mr. Blum said, however, that while he wished the court had taken the step of invalidating the program, "if they are excited about this ruling, I think it's gravely misplaced."
Ms. Fisher, who now lives in Austin, Tex., and says she plays in a county orchestra and loves to bowl, agreed. "They gave us everything we asked for," she said with a diffident smile.
The lesson Ms. Fisher took away from the experience of taking a case all the way to the Supreme Court? "Stick by your ideals, even if it means some personal sacrifice."
William Powers Jr., president of the University of Texas at Austin, provided a different view of the decision in a statement released Monday afternoon.
"Today's ruling has no impact on admissions decisions we have already made or any immediate impact on our holistic admissions policy," the statement said.
- John Schwartz 
 2:35 P.M. | Courthouse Crowd Still Waiting for Main Event 
Affirmative action has historically been an explosive issue in American society. But in front of the Supreme Court, the rainbow-festooned crowd had little interest in the ruling on colorblind admissions issued by the justices Monday. Dozens of gay rights advocates waved flags and held signs in support of same-sex marriage as they waited to hear decisions on two cases that would affect gays and lesbians across the nation.
But the court did not rule on the federal Defense of Marriage Act or Proposition 8, California's gay marriage ban.
"I came up specifically for this. I am really disappointed. It just shows a lack of courage on the court's part," said Bob Kunst, a gay rights advocate from Miami. "Why keep the country divided? The majority of the country is with us, let's come together."
Many seemed to be detached from the proceedings inside the building and said they were not aware the court did not make a decision on gay marriage.
The Supreme Court is in its final week of session and has only a few days left to issue decisions on pending cases. The court said Monday that it would issue more decisions Tuesday morning at 10.
- Erin Banco 
 1:55 P.M. | Four Questions for Ada Meloy 
 Ada Meloy is the general counsel at the American Council on Education, which represents college and university presidents. She previously spent 28 years at New York University's Office of Legal Counsel. 
 Q. How would you summarize the decision in a single sentence? 
 A. The Supreme Court today affirmed the educational benefits of diversity on college and university campuses, allowing institutions to continue considering race and ethnicity as one factor in the admissions process as long as they show their plans are precisely tailored and necessary to achieve their goals.
 Q. Did anything in in it - or in the justices' votes - surprise you? 
 A. We were not expecting a 7-to-1 vote, regardless of what decision the court reached. While not surprised, we were gratified that the court affirmed the compelling government interest in diversity on college and university campuses.
 Q. How broad of an effect do you think the ruling is likely to have? Will it affect admissions policies anywhere other than the University of Texas, and will it affect areas outside higher education? 
 A. The Fisher decision has the potential to affect any college or university that considers race and ethnicity in the admissions process. The ruling does seem very much focused on higher education, but like any Supreme Court ruling it could set a precedent that will impact other parts of our society.
 Q. What's next for affirmative action? 
 A. It will take time to analyze the Fisher ruling and its impact on the use of race and ethnicity in the college admissions process. But college and universities that do use race and ethnicity as a factor should review their admissions policies to make sure they can document why that is necessary to achieving their goals.
- The New York Times 
 1:48 P.M. | Four Questions for Lee Cheng 
 Lee Cheng is a co-founder and secretary of the Asian American Legal Foundation, which was established in 1994. He was the co-author of an amicus brief in Fisher v. the University of Texas at Austin, arguing against the university's affirmative-action program. 
 Q. How would you summarize the decision in a single sentence? 
 A. The expansion of the Grutter doctrine has been halted: the court ruled today that universities like the University of Texas cannot discriminate on the basis of race, no matter how well-intentioned, and that the means and effects of all race-based programs must be subjected to the highest standards of review by courts.
 Q. Did anything in in it - or in the justices' votes - surprise you? 
The court's decision in Fisher v. Texas was not surprising. It was the most likely decision possible among the various options - the type of Solomonic baby splitting that Supreme Court justices seem to love.
We were surprised by the size of the majority in this decision, and the absence of more concurrences and dissents. We did not
expect Justices Breyer or Sotomator to join the majority, but are glad that so many of the justices were willing to recognize that all race-based programs should be questioned and challenged to determine whether they are indeed sufficiently designed to and actually
achieve their purported societal benefits.
 Q. How broad of an effect do you think the ruling is likely to have? Will it affect admissions policies anywhere other than the University of Texas, and will it affect areas outside higher education? 
 A. The court ruled today that all race-based programs, whether in higher education or not, must be, more than ever, subjected to the highest level of judicial scrutiny. I can see challenges to programs across the country in higher and even K-12 education, and eventually in employment and contracting.
 Q. What's next for affirmative action? 
 A. While the use of race as one of many factors to consider continues to be permitted, as it was in Grutter, the court arguably enhanced the level of scrutiny for all programs using race as a consideration based on the means used and the effects of such programs. It's like the court is theoretically allowing race to be considered but also requiring accountability for all programs using race.
In terms of tangible effects, the decision likely means two things: a) the expansion of the number and sophistication of programs
that use race in admissions, and b) additional litigation challenging race-based programs across the country.
- The New York Times 
 1:02 P.M. | Four Questions for Desiree C. Boykin 
 Desiree C. Boykin is the interim general counsel and assistant secretary of the United Negro College Fund. She is a co-author of a recent amicus brief to the Supreme Court on Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin, arguing for the university's affirmative-action program.

 Q. How would you summarize the decision in a single sentence? 
A. In requiring the lower court to follow the standards set forth in Grutter, the Supreme Court has preserved its earlier holding that a
diverse learning environment is a compelling interest that benefits all students and our country as a whole.
 Q. Did anything in in it - or in the justices' votes - surprise you? 
 A. No. In remanding the case, the court is requiring that its prior rulings in Grutter and Bakke are followed and that the appropriate burden of proof is applied.
 Q. How broad of an effect do you think the ruling is likely to have? Will it affect admissions policies anywhere other than the University of Texas, and will it affect areas outside higher education? 
 A. Any impact to admissions policies will not be known until after the lower court's review.
 Q. What's next for affirmative action? 
 A. We believe that the University of Texas at Austin's admissions policy is a carefully crafted policy that will ultimately be upheld by the courts.
- The New York Times 
 12:50 P.M. | Four Questions for Roger Clegg 
 Roger Clegg is the president and general counsel of the Center for Equal Opportunity, a conservative organization. From 1982 to 1993, he held a number of positions at the United States Department of Justice, and he argued three cases before the United States Supreme Court. 
 Q. How would you summarize the decision in a single sentence? 
 A. Strict means strict.
 Q. Did anything in in it - or in the justices' votes - surprise you? 
 A. That we had to wait so long for a decision that, while ultimately positive, is still quite limited and brief.
 Q. How broad of an effect do you think the ruling is likely to have? 
 A. The combination of the ruling and the run-up to the ruling - in which it has become clear how increasingly unpopular and discredited racial preferences in admissions are - will result in some serious soul-searching among university presidents on whether "diversity" is really worth the price of racial discrimination. At least, I hope so.
 Q. Will it affect admissions policies anywhere other than the University of Texas, and will it affect areas outside higher education? 
 A. Certainly the soul-searching I describe should take place at all universities that use racial preferences. It might cause for some corporate soul-searching, too, since unfortunately corporate America has bought into the diversity-via-discrimination approach in a big way.
 Q. What's next for affirmative action? 
Preferential treatment based on race, ethnicity, and sex - the sort of "affirmative action" that is objectionable as a policy and legal matter - will continue its steady march to the dustbin of history. And deservedly so.
- The New York Times 
 12:44 P.M. | Four Questions for Richard D. Kahlenberg 
 Richard D. Kahlenberg is a senior fellow at the Century Foundation. He is the author of "The Remedy," a 1996 book about affirmative action, as well as a co-author of the recent report "A Better Affirmative Action." 
 Q. How would you summarize the decision in a single sentence? 
 A. By making it much harder for universities to employ racial preferences, the Supreme Court has paved the way for a new affirmative action based on economic disadvantage.
 Q. Did anything in in it - or in the justices' votes - surprise you? 
 A. I was surprised that the court sent the case back to the lower court and surprised that Justices Breyer and Sotomayor were willing to sign on to a tougher standard - that on the question of narrow tailoring "the university receives no deference," and the requirement that "judges must ultimately be satisfied that no workable race-neutral alternative would produce the educational benefits of diversity."
 Q. How broad of an effect do you think the ruling is likely to have? Will it affect admissions policies anywhere other than the University of Texas, and will it affect areas outside higher education? 
 A. The effect will be national in scope, influencing the admissions policies at both public and private colleges and universities across the country. In the past universities have relied heavily on racial preferences and given almost no consideration to economic disadvantage. By requiring universities to first pursue "race-neutral" alternatives like economic status, the Supreme Court could effectively flip the equation. If universities want racial diversity, they will first have to try to achieve it by using alternative means such as economic status.
 Q. What's next for affirmative action? 
 A. While the Supreme Court left the door open a crack for using race (in cases where "no workable race-neutral alternatives" are available), economic affirmative action will likely come to predominate in college admissions over time. In the 2007 Supreme Court striking down racial integration plans in Louisville and Seattle in 2007, Justice Kennedy described ways in which race could still be used, but virtually all school districts pursuing integration shifted to emphasizing socioeconomic status rather than race. The new higher standard is likely to discourage universities from using race and opening themselves up to litigation. If that occurs, the decision will be a boon to low-income and working-class students of all racial backgrounds who have to date been effectively shut out of selective colleges.
- The New York Times 
 12:36 P.M. | How Minorities Have Fared in States With Bans 
In states that have banned affirmative action in college admissions, prominent public universities have tended to enroll fewer black and Hispanic freshmen. This interactive graphic shows which prominent colleges have been the most successful at keeping pace with demographic changes. View the Graphic
- Graphics Desk 
 12:13 P.M. | Four Questions for Sheryll Cashin 
 Sheryll Cashin is a law professor at Georgetown University and a former law clerk to Thurgood Marshall. Next year, she will publish a book entitled "Place Not Race: Creating Opportunity for All After Affirmative Action." 
 Q. How would you summarize the decision in a single sentence? 
 A. After nearly a year of debate and anxiety on both sides of the question, the court in a 7-to-1 decision largely maintained the status quo, i.e., universities have a compelling interest in pursuing diversity but they cannot use rigid racial quotas.
 Q. Did anything in in it - or in the justices' votes - surprise you? 
 A. I was surprised that the court left intact its decision in Grutter (the Michigan affirmative case). Although Justice Kennedy dissented in that case, writing for the majority today he took Grutter and Bakke as givens. Justice Kennedy seems to have made his peace with Grutter in part by putting his gloss on it. He is very comfortable with the idea that universities have a compelling interest in the educational benefits of diversity. He reaffirmed that they even deserve deference on why diversity produces educational benefits. He made it clear, however, that any use of race must be narrowly tailored and that judges, not universities, get to decide what narrow tailoring means. His bottom line was this: when an affirmative action plan gets challenged in court, the court must be satisfied that there are "no workable race-neutral alternatives" to achieve the educational benefits of diversity.
 Q. How broad of an effect do you think the ruling is likely to have? Will it affect admissions policies anywhere other than the University of Texas, and will it affect areas outside higher education? 
 A. In the near term I think many universities are breathing a sigh of relief. In theory, a race-based affirmative action plan can still survive strict scrutiny, although Justice Kennedy has placed his thumb on the scale against it in demanding that universities that are sued must make a showing that there were no viable race-neutral alternatives. I think universities will be reviewing their admissions plans carefully over the summer and watching to see what happens to the University of Texas' plan on remand. The decision is more important for U.T. than other universities; U.T. could lose on remand.
 Q. What's next for affirmative action? 
 A. There will always be another Abigail Fisher. Opponents in this case did not ask the court to overrule Grutter. There are four votes to overrule Grutter, but Kennedy has indicated in this opinion that he is not inclined to do it. I think opponents of affirmative action will keep chipping away at it through litigation and in the political sphere, lobbying Republicans in state legislatures to adopt bans. We are up to eight state bans, and this opinion may galvanize more political opposition. I also think university admissions offices will continue experimenting with race-neutral alternatives that help create racial and economic diversity in a less divisive way. Hopefully the anxiety about lawsuits will cause universities to revisit admissions policies that are exclusionary, like standardized tests and legacy admissions.
- The New York Times 
 11:57 A.M. | Decision Lands on a Busy Day at the White House 
White House officials in every administration like to brag about being able to multitask during days when the news hits them from all sides.
This is one of those days.
National security officials are chasing Edward Snowden, the National Security Agency leaker, across the globe. The immigration battle in the Senate is entering its final week. The president is preparing for a huge climate policy announcement on Tuesday. Diplomatic officials are bracing for the possibility that Nelson Mandela might die in hours before the president's trip to the African continent.
Oh, and the Supreme Court on Monday morning issued a ruling on affirmative action programs at the nation's colleges, the first of what could be landmark rulings in four cases this week that have broad implications for the nation.
"The president has to be able to walk, chew gum, juggle and ride a unicycle all at the same time," Robert Gibbs, Mr. Obama's first press secretary, said once.
A statement from the West Wing on the affirmative action ruling is expected soon (though the White House counsel's office, no doubt, is in the same position as everyone else: trying to figure out exactly what it means).
The affirmative action statement would follow a series of late-night communications by the national security staff at the White House on Mr. Snowden, who appears not to have boarded the flight to Cuba that everyone expected him to be on Monday morning.
And later Monday, White House officials are holding a briefing for reporters to preview the president's remarks on climate change. Mr. Obama is expected to announce his intention to propose new regulations limiting carbon dioxide emissions from existing power plants.
Meanwhile, the president's travel and protocol offices are waiting to see what happens with Mr. Mandela, who has been in a hospital for three weeks, battling a long-standing lung infection. On Sunday, South African officials said his condition had become critical.
Mr. Obama is slated to leave Wednesday for his weeklong, three-country trip that includes two days in South Africa. If Mr. Mandela dies ahead of the trip, it is unclear how that could change Mr. Obama's travel plans.
For the moment, White House officials are just going to have to be flexible. Or, as Jay Carney, the president's current press secretary, said recently, "We can walk and chew gum at the same time."
- Michael D. Shear 
 11:36 A.M. | Four Questions for Richard Primus 
 Richard Primus is a professor specializing in constitutional law at the University of Michigan Law School. He is a former Rhodes Scholar and served as a clerk to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg. 
 Q. How would you summarize the decision in a single sentence? 
 A. The Michigan model of affirmative action - upheld by the court in 2003 - remains valid for now, and the court will watch universities closely to make sure they don't go an inch beyond it.
 Q. Did anything in in it - or in the justices' votes - surprise you?
 A. Many people predicted that a 5-to-4 conservative majority would use this case to eliminate affirmative action. Those predictions were probably based more on fear (from the left) and wishful thinking (from the right) than on careful consideration of what the center of this court - Justice Kennedy - has said in the past. The result in this case is perfectly Kennedyesque: universities may consider race to ensure diverse student bodies, but only if they really need to, and Justice Kennedy's court will be in charge of deciding whether they really need to.
What's remarkable is how broad a coalition agreed to handle the case in this moderate way. Sometime in the future, the ultimate question of the validity of race-based affirmative action may have to be confronted again. But for now, even most of the court's conservative justices declined to use this occasion to say that they believe affirmative action to be flatly unconstitutional.
 Q. How broad of an effect do you think the ruling is likely to have? Will it affect admissions policies anywhere other than the University of Texas, and will it affect areas outside higher education?
 A. The ruling will change little. It reaffirms the status quo, with emphasis on the court's own role as arbiter. After a lot of buildup and drama, this round ends with a whimper and not a bang.
 If we believed that the court was in the business of applying precedent scrupulously and cautiously, this shouldn't surprise us. The big story here is the gap between the public's expectation of big news and the quiet, technical resolution the court chose. For which there can be two explanations: Either the public has come to expect the court to act even more ideologically than it does, or else affirmative action touches a nerve raw enough that we expect it to produce fireworks. Or both.
 Q. What's next for affirmative action? 

A. There will be more rounds of argument about whether "race-neutral alternatives" can produce diversity. "Race-neutral" needs to be in quotation marks, because people have very different ideas about what counts as race-neutral. (Is class-based affirmative action race-neutral if it is intended to produce racial diversity?) Nobody can predict where those arguments will end up, and nobody knows what the court will look like when the issue comes back - which it eventually will. For now, though, this decision will change little about either what universities do in practice or how people more broadly talk about affirmative action. The conversation goes on with just a minor bump.
- The New York Times 
 11:21 A.M. | Bans on Racial Preferences Have Had Mixed Results 
Though Monday's decision will most likely have few immediate implications for affirmative action programs around the country, it may represent the start of a new wave of challenges to the use of race in admissions decisions.
The following states have already banned affirmative action, a move that blocks consideration of race or ethnicity in admission to state colleges: California, Washington, Florida, Michigan, Arizona, New Hampshire, Nebraska and Oklahoma.
In most states, the bans have been followed by an initial sharp drop in enrollment of black, Hispanic and Native American students. The states have responded with a range of policies intended to boost diversity through race-blind means.
But the results have been mixed, both racially and socioeconomically. The affected state universities vary widely in the racial mix of their state populations, their selectivity, their levels of support from state government and how aggressively they have pursued diversity programs.
- Richard P&#233;rez-Pe&#241;a 
 11:14 A.M. | Four Questions for Stuart Taylor 
 Stuart Taylor Jr. has covered the Supreme Court and other matters for National Journal, The New York Times, Newsweek, The American Lawyer and Legal Times. Last year, he and Richard Sander published "Mismatch: How Affirmative Action Hurts Students It's Intended to Help, and Why Universities Won't Admit It." 
 Q: How would you summarize the decision in a single sentence? 
 A. This is an extremely narrow decision reversing the lower court for giving too much credence to the "good faith" of the University of Texas in its use of race and for failing to consider race-neutral alternatives.
 Q. Did anything in in it - or in the justices' votes - surprise you? 
 A. Yes. It was widely expected to be a 5-to-3 decision (with Justice Kagan recused) cutting back on universities' ability to use racial preferences. Instead, Justice Kennedy's majority opinion did not change the law at all.
 Q. How broad of an effect do you think the ruling is likely to have? Will it affect admissions policies anywhere other than the University of Texas, and will it affect areas outside higher education? 
 A. The effect will be very narrow, and the lower court's options include reaffirming its support for the Texas racial-preference plan that the Supreme Court had agreed to review.[#x200b]
 Q. What's next for affirmative action?

 A. The Supreme Court will hear arguments this fall in another big case, Schuette v. Coalition to Defend Affirmative Action, involving a 2006 ballot measure amending the Michigan constitution to prohibit (among other things) racial preferences in state university admissions. The United States Court of Appeals for the 6th Circuit struck down that provision by a party-line vote, with eight Democratic appointees outvoting seven Republican appointees. The majority reasoned that it violated the Constitution's guarantee of equal protection of the laws for a state constitutional amendment to require equal treatment of all racial groups, because the ballot measure had made it harder for racial minorities than for other groups (such as alumni children) to win preferential treatment. Dissenters countered that "a state does not deny equal treatment by mandating it," in the words of Judge Jeffrey Sutton.
- The New York Times 
 11:09 A.M. | Video: Affirmative Action's Contentious History 
- The New York Times 
 10:51 A.M. | Court Calls for More Scrutiny 
The Supreme Court ruled Monday that lower courts did not apply a sufficiently high level of scrutiny to the University of Texas at Austin's use of race in admissions decisions, sending the case back to one of those lower courts to be reconsidered.
The decision will most likely have few immediate implications for affirmative action programs around the country, including in Texas. But it may represent the start of a new wave of challenges to the use of race in admissions decisions.
In a 7-to-1 decision, with Justice Anthony Kennedy writing the majority opinion, the court ruled that the lower court did not use a legal standard known as strict scrutiny to assess the university's program.
"Strict scrutiny," the opinion read, "does not permit a court to accept a school's assertion that its admissions process uses race in a permissible way without closely examining how the process works in practice."
Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg was the lone dissenter in the case, Fisher v. the University of Texas.
Read the decision.
- The New York Times 
 10:47 A.M. | On Affirmative Action, Focus Is on Public Schools 
All of the major rulings on affirmative action, from Bakke in 1978 to Hopwood in 1996 to Grutter and Gratz in 2003 to Fisher today, have involved public universities.
But legal experts say it is only a matter of time before similar challenges are filed against private colleges, as well - and they are likely to succeed.
Plaintiffs have challenged affirmative action as a violation of the 14th Amendment, whose equal protection clause bars discrimination by government, but not by private parties. But Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 prohibits discrimination by any entity that uses federal funds - which describes almost all colleges and universities.
Many private college administrators say they already operate under the assumption that the restrictions the Supreme Court has placed on public universities also apply to them.
- Richard P&#233;rez-Pe&#241;a 
 10:43 A.M. | Public Is Split Along Racial and Partisan Lines 
The public is deeply divided across racial and partisan lines on affirmative action, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll conducted early this month.
The poll found that more than half of Americans, 53 percent, favor affirmative action programs for minorities in hiring, promoting and college admissions, while 38 percent oppose them. (Other polls in the past that have asked about giving minorities "preference" have shown less support.)
Three-quarters of black respondents support such programs, but fewer than half of whites agree. And while support is at 75 percent among Democrats, it drops to 51 percent among independents and falls even further to just 37 percent among Republicans.
Among those who favor such programs, most say the main reason is to increase diversity, rather than to make up for discrimination.
- Dalia Sussman

 10:29 A.M. | Inside the Decision 
The court's decision seems to instruct lower courts on how to handle cases concerning affirmative action.
From SCOTUSblog:
Here's the money quote: "The reviewing court must ultimately be satisfied that no workable race-neutral alternatives would produce the educational benefits of diversity."
- The New York Times 
 10:28 A.M. | History of Affirmative Action and Important Cases 
Texas was one of the first states to have a ban on affirmative action, and though the prohibition was later overturned, it has had a lasting effect on higher education in that state, and an influence on the Fisher case.
In March 1996, in Hopwood v. Texas, the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals struck down affirmative action, in a case involving admission to the University of Texas Law School. The ruling held sway in the states of that circuit, Texas, Louisiana and Mississippi.
It was in response to that ruling that Texas adopted the practice of admitting all students in the top 10 percent of their high school classes to the state's universities, including the flagship at Austin.

Other Cases 
The End of Quotas: Regents of the University of California v. Bakke, 1978
The high court ruled that racial quotas in the college admissions process violate the Equal Protection Clause, a part of the 14th Amendment. But, it said, race can be a factor in admission decisions. That said, California has the oldest lasting ban on affirmative action, adopted by voters in November 1996 as Proposition 209.
The Michigan Cases: Gratz v. Bollinger and Grutter v. Bollinger, 2003
How exactly can a university factor in race? Not with points, the court ruled. Jennifer Gratz sued the University of Michigan when she was not admitted as an undergraduate in 1995. The college assigned each applicant points. Race could offer up to 20 points. Leadership and service, up to five. With a vote of six to three, the court said that system violated the Equal Protection Clause.
By a vote of five to four, however, the justices rejected the parallel argument of Barbara Grutter. In 1996, she was denied admission from the University of Michigan's Law School, which, wrote Sandra Day O'Connor, used a "narrowly tailored use of race in admissions decisions to further a compelling interest in obtaining the educational benefits that flow from a diverse student body."
- Richard P&#233;rez-Pe&#241;a and Sarah Wheaton 
 10:19 A.M. | Court Rules in Affirmative Action Case 
The Supreme Court issued a ruling on Monday in Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin, a case concerning affirmative action.
From SCOTUSblog:
The opinion by Kennedy. The Fifth Circuit is vacated and remanded. The holding is because the Fifth Circuit did not hold the university to the demanding burden of strict scrutiny articulated in Grutter and Bakke, its decision affiming the district court's grant of summary judgment was incorrect.
There is one dissent. It is 7-1. Ginsburg dissents alone. There are separate concurring opinions by Scalia and Thomas. Kagan was recused.
- The New York Times 
 9:32 A.M. | Explaining The Times's Coverage of the Decision 
We realize that people will be eager to know what the ruling means as soon as it comes out (and you can read the decision yourself when it is posted on the court's Web site). But we also want to point out that the immediate descriptions of any ruling may not be very meaningful.
For one thing, a ruling could be complicated, as were last year's health care ruling and the 2000 Bush v. Gore ruling, and not amenable to instant summarizing. The court could even announce one portion of a decision - especially on same-sex marriage, given the two different cases - before it releases another portion.
Dozens of Times journalists, in Washington, New York and around the country, are covering the ruling and the reaction to it by the public and those affected by it. At the center of the coverage is Adam Liptak, the Supreme Court reporter (and a lawyer) of The Times, who will be in court to hear the ruling.
We plan to explain the ruling the moment we feel comfortable with its basic meaning - which could be almost immediately. We promise not to bombard you with guesswork or unintelligible legal technicalities. The Times will also run blog posts from the legal experts at SCOTUSblog on our own site, as well as ask other outside experts to help readers understand the decision. Once the fundamentals of the ruling are clear, Times reporters and editors will be analyzing it in real time, on our live blog dedicated to the ruling and on stories appearing across our digital platforms. We will also post updates to Twitter on @thecaucus and @nytimes, and post selected reactions from readers.
We expect to have Mr. Liptak's initial story about any ruling by late morning or shortly after noon, not long after the court's session has ended. Whatever happens Thursday, we also expect at least one major ruling to come next week.
Thanks for being with us.
- The New York Times

HEADLINE: Deals in the Works Involving 2 Luxury Retailers

BYLINE: MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED


HIGHLIGHT: Neiman Marcus filed to go public on Monday, more than eight years after agreeing to go private in a sale to the investment firms TPG Capital and Warburg Pincus. 

 BODY:
High-end fashion still has plenty of appeal for Wall Street as two of the biggest luxury brands tested their worth to the market.
The private equity owners of Neiman Marcus, one of the country's most upscale department stores and the owner of Bergdorf Goodman in Manhattan, on Monday filed for an initial public offering, the first step toward becoming a publicly traded company.
 And the owner of Lord & Taylor is exploring a potential bid for Saks Inc., the 90-year-old department store chain, according to someone who had been briefed on the matter but was not authorized to speak publicly. 
Interest in both companies highlights how the market for Chanel dresses and Louis Vuitton handbags has stayed strong, despite the financial crisis. Revenue at the two retailers hovers just below 2008 levels.
The filing of Neiman Marcus has been long expected, as private equity firms are moving to sell their holdings to take advantage of relatively robust stock markets. The retailer, known for selling wares like Christian Louboutin heels and $100,000 aquatic jet packs, agreed to sell itself to the investment firms TPG Capital and Warburg Pincus more than eight years ago.
TPG and Warburg Pincus had explored selling the company before, including in 2007, but held on as the weakening economy began to roil nearly every segment of the retail industry. In a low, the company reported a $668 million loss in 2009, immediately after the financial crisis.
Neiman Marcus, which operates 41 stores around the country and other brands, has rebounded since then. On Monday, the retailer disclosed that it earned $140.1 million last year, in addition to $4.3 billion in revenue, its best fiscal year since before the 2008 crisis. For the 39 weeks that ended April 27, it made a $160.8 million profit, up 6 percent from the period last year.
The prospectus was light on other details, including how many shares the company plans to sell, at what price and on what stock exchange it will list.
Saks may find itself joining forces with other department stores with rich histories. Among the potential bidders for the chain is said to be Richard A. Baker, the shopping mall developer-turned-retailing mogul who owns both Lord & Taylor and Hudson's Bay.
Among other potential buyers or investors are Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the private equity giant, and the Qatar Investment Authority, a sovereign wealth fund for the Middle Eastern emirate, the person briefed on the matter said.
The destinies of Neiman Marcus and Saks at one point could have been intertwined. K.K.R. approached Neiman Marcus's owners this year with a preliminary proposal to merge the retailer with Saks, a person briefed on the discussions said previously, potentially creating one of the biggest upscale department stores in the country. But TPG and Warburg Pincus were cool to the idea.
For Mr. Baker, chief executive of Hudson's Bay, the parent of The Bay stores in Canada and Lord & Taylor in the United States, an acquisition of Saks would cap an extraordinary run of deals. In 2006, at the market peak, he acquired Lord & Taylor for $1.2 billion. He later acquired Hudson's Bay and combined the two into one company, which posted about $4.1 billion in revenue during its 2012 fiscal year.
Last November, Mr. Baker orchestrated an initial public offering of Hudson's Bay, listing the company on the Toronto Stock Exchange.
Adding Saks to his portfolio holds great appeal to Mr. Baker, 47, who lives in Greenwich, Conn., and whose business is based in New York. In the United States, the flagship stores of Saks and Lord & Taylor are 11 blocks apart on Fifth Avenue. And there is also growth potential in Canada for both the 43 Saks Fifth Avenue department stores, and the 66 stores that are part of its discount arm, Off 5th.
If Mr. Baker bids for Saks, presumably real estate could be part of the attraction. After acquiring Hudson's Bay, he struck a complex deal to sell the rights to leases on an underperforming division of Hudson's Bay to Target for about $1.8 billion. The deal enabled him to pay down a large amount of debt.
Mr. Baker's interest in Saks was first reported on Monday by Women's Wear Daily.
