HEADLINE: Live Analysis of Supreme Court Decision on Affirmative Action

BYLINE: THE NEW YORK TIMES


HIGHLIGHT: The Supreme Court ruled on Thursday on Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin, a case concerning affirmative action. Times reporters and editors are analyzing the decision and its implications, as well as the public&#8217;s reaction to it. 

 BODY:
 The Supreme Court ruled Monday that lower courts did not apply a sufficiently high level of scrutiny to the University of Texas' use of race in admissions decisions, sending the case back to one of those lower courts to be reconsidered.
 12:44 P.M. | Four Questions for Richard D. Kahlenberg 
 Richard D. Kahlenberg is a senior fellow at The Century Foundation. He is author of "The Remedy," a 1996 book about affirmative action, as well as a coauthor of the recent report "A Better Affirmative Action." 
 Q. How would you summarize the decision in a single sentence? 
 A. By making it much harder for universities to employ racial preferences, the Supreme Court has paved the way for a new affirmative action based on economic disadvantage.
 Q. Did anything in in it - or in the justices' votes - surprise you? 
 A. I was surprised that the court sent the case back to the lower court and surprised that Justices Breyer and Sotomayor were willing to sign on to a tougher standard - that on the question of narrow tailoring "the university receives no deference," and the requirement that "judges must ultimately be satisfied that no workable race-neutral alternative would produce the educational benefits of diversity."
 Q. How broad of an effect do you think the ruling is likely to have? Will it affect admissions policies anywhere other than the University of Texas, and will it affect areas outside higher education? 
 A. The effect will be national in scope, influencing the admissions policies at both public and private colleges and universities across the country. In the past universities have relied heavily on racial preferences and given almost no consideration to economic disadvantage. By requiring universities to first pursue "race-neutral" alternatives like economic status, the Supreme Court could effectively flip the equation. If universities want racial diversity, they will first have to try to achieve it by using alternative means such as economic status.
 Q. What's next for affirmative action? 
 A. While the Supreme Court left the door open a crack for using race (in cases where "no workable race-neutral alternatives" are available) economic affirmative action will likely come to predominate in college admissions over time. In the 2007 Supreme Court striking down racial integration plans in Louisville and Seattle in 2007, Justice Kennedy described ways in which race could still be used, but virtually all school districts pursuing integration shifted to emphasizing socioeconomic status rather than race. The new higher standard is likely to discourage universities from using race and opening themselves up to litigation. If that occurs, the decision will be a boon to low income and working class students of all racial backgrounds who have to date been effectively shut out of selective colleges.
- The New York Times 
 12:36 P.M. | How Minorities Have Fared in States With Bans 
In states that have banned affirmative action in college admissions, prominent public universities have tended to enroll fewer black and Hispanic freshmen. This interactive graphic shows which prominent colleges have been the most successful at keeping pace with demographic changes. View the Graphic
- Graphics Desk 
 12:13 P.M. | Four Questions for Sheryll Cashin 
 Sheryll Cashin is a law professor at Georgetown and former law clerk to Thurgood Marshall. Next year, she will publish a book entitled, "Place Not Race: Creating Opportunity for All After Affirmative Action." 
 Q. How would you summarize the decision in a single sentence? 
 A. After nearly a year of debate and anxiety on both sides of the question, the court in a 7 to 1 decision largely maintained the status quo, i.e. universities have a compelling interest in pursuing diversity but they cannot use rigid racial quotas.
 Q. Did anything in in it - or in the justices' votes - surprise you? 
 A. I was surprised that the court left intact its decision in Grutter (the Michigan affirmative case). Although Justice Kennedy dissented in that case, writing for the majority today he took Grutter and Bakke as givens. Justice Kennedy seems to have made his peace with Grutter in part by putting his gloss on it. He is very comfortable with the idea that universities have a compelling interest in the educational benefits of diversity. He reaffirmed that they even deserve deference on why diversity produces educational benefits. He made it clear, however, that any use of race must be narrowly tailored and that judges, not universities, get to decide what narrow tailoring means. His bottom line was this: when an affirmative action plan gets challenged in court, the court must be satisfied that there are "no workable race-neutral alternatives" to achieve the educational benefits of diversity.
 Q. How broad of an effect do you think the ruling is likely to have? Will it affect admissions policies anywhere other than the University of Texas, and will it affect areas outside higher education? 
 A. In the near term I think many universities are breathing a sigh of relief. In theory, a race-based affirmative action plan can still survive strict scrutiny although Justice Kennedy has placed his thumb on the scale against it in demanding that universities that are sued must make a showing that there were no viable race-neutral alternatives. I think universities will be reviewing their admissions plans carefully over the summer and watching to see what happens to the University of Texas's plan on remand. The decision is more important for U.T. than other universities; U.T. could lose on remand.
 Q. What's next for affirmative action? 
 A. There will always be another Abigail Fisher. Opponents in this case did not ask the court to overrule Grutter. There are four votes to overrule Grutter but Kennedy has indicated in this opinion that he is not inclined to do it. I think opponents of affirmative action will keep chipping away at it through litigation and in the political sphere, lobbying Republicans in state legislators to adopt bans. We are up to eight state bans, and this opinion may galvanize more political opposition. I also think university admissions offices will continue experimenting with race-neutral alternatives that help create racial and economic diversity in a less divisive way. Hopefully the anxiety about lawsuits will cause universities to revisit admissions policies that are exclusionary, like standardized tests and legacy admissions.
- The New York Times 
 11:57 A.M. | Decision Lands on a Busy Day at the White House 
White House officials in every administration like to brag about being able to multitask during days when the news hits them from all sides.
This is one of those days.
National security officials are chasing Edward Snowden, the National Security Agency leaker, across the globe. The immigration battle in the Senate is entering its final week. The president is preparing for a huge climate policy announcement on Tuesday. Diplomatic officials are bracing for the possibility that Nelson Mandela might die in hours before the president's trip to the African continent.
Oh, and the Supreme Court on Monday morning issued a ruling on affirmative action programs at the nation's colleges, the first of what could be landmark rulings in four cases this week that have broad implications for the nation.
"The president has to be able to walk, chew gum, juggle and ride a unicycle all at the same time," Robert Gibbs, Mr. Obama's first press secretary, said once.
A statement from the West Wing on the affirmative action ruling is expected soon (though the White House counsel's office, no doubt, is in the same position as everyone else: trying to figure out exactly what it means).
The affirmative action statement would follow a series of late-night communications by the national security staff at the White House on Mr. Snowden, who appears not to have boarded the flight to Cuba that everyone expected him to be on Monday morning.
And later Monday, White House officials are holding a briefing for reporters to preview the president's remarks on climate change. Mr. Obama is expected to announce his intention to propose new regulations limiting carbon dioxide emissions from existing power plants.
Meanwhile, the president's travel and protocol offices are waiting to see what happens with Mr. Mandela, who has been in a hospital for three weeks, battling a long-standing lung infection. On Sunday, South African officials said his condition had become critical.
Mr. Obama is slated to leave Wednesday for his weeklong, three-country trip that includes two days in South Africa. If Mr. Mandela dies ahead of the trip, it is unclear how that could change Mr. Obama's travel plans.
For the moment, White House officials are just going to have to be flexible. Or, as Jay Carney, the president's current press secretary, said recently, "We can walk and chew gum at the same time."
- Michael D. Shear 
 11:36 A.M. | Four Questions for Richard Primus 
 Richard Primus is a professor specializing in constitutional law at the University of Michigan Law School. He is a former Rhodes Scholar and served as a clerk to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg. 
 Q. How would you summarize the decision in a single sentence? 
 A. The Michigan model of affirmative action - upheld by the court in 2003 - remains valid for now, and the court will watch universities closely to make sure they don't go an inch beyond it.
 Q. Did anything in in it - or in the justices' votes - surprise you?
 A. Many people predicted that a 5-to-4 conservative majority would use this case to eliminate affirmative action. Those predictions were probably based more on fear (from the left) and wishful thinking (from the right) than on careful consideration of what the center of this court - Justice Kennedy - has said in the past. The result in this case is perfectly Kennedyesque: universities may consider race to ensure diverse student bodies, but only if they really need to, and Justice Kennedy's court will be in charge of deciding whether they really need to.
What's remarkable is how broad a coalition agreed to handle the case in this moderate way. Sometime in the future, the ultimate question of the validity of race-based affirmative action may have to be confronted again. But for now, even most of the court's conservative justices declined to use this occasion to say that they believe affirmative action to be flatly unconstitutional.
 Q. How broad of an effect do you think the ruling is likely to have? Will it affect admissions policies anywhere other than the University of Texas, and will it affect areas outside higher education?
 A. The ruling will change little. It reaffirms the status quo, with emphasis on the court's own role as arbiter. After a lot of buildup and drama, this round ends with a whimper and not a bang.
 If we believed that the court was in the business of applying precedent scrupulously and cautiously, this shouldn't surprise us. The big story here is the gap between the public's expectation of big news and the quiet, technical resolution the court chose. For which there can be two explanations: Either the public has come to expect the court to act even more ideologically than it does, or else affirmative action touches a nerve raw enough that we expect it to produce fireworks. Or both.
 Q. What's next for affirmative action? 

A. There will be more rounds of argument about whether "race-neutral alternatives" can produce diversity. "Race-neutral" needs to be in quotation marks, because people have very different ideas about what counts as race-neutral. (Is class-based affirmative action race-neutral if it is intended to produce racial diversity?) Nobody can predict where those arguments will end up, and nobody knows what the court will look like when the issue comes back - which it eventually will. For now, though, this decision will change little about either what universities do in practice or how people more broadly talk about affirmative action. The conversation goes on with just a minor bump.
- The New York Times 
 11:21 A.M. | Bans on Racial Preferences Have Had Mixed Results 
Though Monday's decision will most likely have few immediate implications for affirmative action programs around the country, it may represent the start of a new wave of challenges to the use of race in admissions decisions.
The following states have already banned affirmative action, a move that blocks consideration of race or ethnicity in admission to state colleges: California, Washington, Florida, Michigan, Arizona, New Hampshire, Nebraska and Oklahoma.
In most states, the bans have been followed by an initial sharp drop in enrollment of black, Hispanic and Native American students. The states have responded with a range of policies intended to boost diversity through race-blind means.
But the results have been mixed, both racially and socioeconomically. The affected state universities vary widely in the racial mix of their state populations, their selectivity, their levels of support from state government and how aggressively they have pursued diversity programs.
- Richard P&#233;rez-Pe&#241;a 
 11:14 A.M. | Four Questions for Stuart Taylor 
 Stuart Taylor Jr. has covered the Supreme Court and other matters for National Journal, The New York Times, Newsweek, The American Lawyer and Legal Times. Last year, he and Richard Sander published "Mismatch: How Affirmative Action Hurts Students It's Intended to Help, and Why Universities Won't Admit It." 
 Q: How would you summarize the decision in a single sentence? 
 A. This is an extremely narrow decision reversing the lower court for giving too much credence to the "good faith" of the University of Texas in its use of race and for failing to consider race-neutral alternatives.
 Q. Did anything in in it - or in the justices' votes - surprise you? 
 A. Yes. It was widely expected to be a 5-to-3 decision (with Justice Kagan recused) cutting back on universities' ability to use racial preferences. Instead, Justice Kennedy's majority opinion did not change the law at all.
 Q. How broad of an effect do you think the ruling is likely to have? Will it affect admissions policies anywhere other than the University of Texas, and will it affect areas outside higher education? 
 A. The effect will be very narrow, and the lower court's options include reaffirming its support for the Texas racial-preference plan that the Supreme Court had agreed to review.[#x200b]
 Q. What's next for affirmative action?

 A. The Supreme Court will hear arguments this fall in another big case, Schuette v. Coalition to Defend Affirmative Action, involving a 2006 ballot measure amending the Michigan constitution to prohibit (among other things) racial preferences in state university admissions. The United States Court of Appeals for the 6th Circuit struck down that provision by a party-line vote, with eight Democratic appointees outvoting seven Republican appointees. The majority reasoned that it violated the Constitution's guarantee of equal protection of the laws for a state constitutional amendment to require equal treatment of all racial groups, because the ballot measure had made it harder for racial minorities than for other groups (such as alumni children) to win preferential treatment. Dissenters countered that "a state does not deny equal treatment by mandating it," in the words of Judge Jeffrey Sutton.
- The New York Times 
 11:09 A.M. | Video: Affirmative Action's Contentious History 
- The New York Times 
 10:51 A.M. | Court Calls for More Scrutiny 
The Supreme Court ruled Monday that lower courts did not apply a sufficiently high level of scrutiny to the University of Texas at Austin's use of race in admissions decisions, sending the case back to one of those lower courts to be reconsidered.
The decision will most likely have few immediate implications for affirmative action programs around the country, including in Texas. But it may represent the start of a new wave of challenges to the use of race in admissions decisions.
In a 7-to-1 decision, with Justice Anthony Kennedy writing the majority opinion, the court ruled that the lower court did not use a legal standard known as strict scrutiny to assess the university's program.
"Strict scrutiny," the opinion read, "does not permit a court to accept a school's assertion that its admissions process uses race in a permissible way without closely examining how the process works in practice."
Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg was the lone dissenter in the case, Fisher v. the University of Texas.
Read the decision.
- The New York Times 
 10:47 A.M. | On Affirmative Action, Focus Is on Public Schools 
All of the major rulings on affirmative action, from Bakke in 1978 to Hopwood in 1996 to Grutter and Gratz in 2003 to Fisher today, have involved public universities.
But legal experts say it is only a matter of time before similar challenges are filed against private colleges, as well - and they are likely to succeed.
Plaintiffs have challenged affirmative action as a violation of the 14th Amendment, whose equal protection clause bars discrimination by government, but not by private parties. But Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 prohibits discrimination by any entity that uses federal funds - which describes almost all colleges and universities.
Many private college administrators say they already operate under the assumption that the restrictions the Supreme Court has placed on public universities also apply to them.
- Richard P&#233;rez-Pe&#241;a 
 10:43 A.M. | Public Is Split Along Racial and Partisan Lines 
The public is deeply divided across racial and partisan lines on affirmative action, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll conducted early this month.
The poll found that more than half of Americans, 53 percent, favor affirmative action programs for minorities in hiring, promoting and college admissions, while 38 percent oppose them. (Other polls in the past that have asked about giving minorities "preference" have shown less support.)
Three-quarters of black respondents support such programs, but fewer than half of whites agree. And while support is at 75 percent among Democrats, it drops to 51 percent among independents and falls even further to just 37 percent among Republicans.
Among those who favor such programs, most say the main reason is to increase diversity, rather than to make up for discrimination.
- Dalia Sussman

 10:29 A.M. | Inside the Decision 
The court's decision seems to instruct lower courts on how to handle cases concerning affirmative action.
From SCOTUSblog:
Here's the money quote: "The reviewing court must ultimately be satisfied that no workable race-neutral alternatives would produce the educational benefits of diversity."
- The New York Times 
 10:28 A.M. | Texas Has History on Affirmative Action 
Texas was one of the first states to have a ban on affirmative action, and though the prohibition was later overturned, it has had a lasting effect on higher education in that state, and an influence on the Fisher case.
In March 1996, in Hopwood v. Texas, the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals struck down affirmative action, in a case involving admission to the University of Texas Law School. The ruling held sway in the states of that circuit, Texas, Louisiana and Mississippi.
It was in response to that ruling that Texas adopted the practice of admitting all students in the top 10 percent of their high school classes to the state's universities, including the flagship at Austin.
But in 2003, in Grutter v. Bollinger, a case involving the University of Michigan, the Supreme Court overturned the Hopwood decision. That allowed state colleges in the Fifth Circuit to return to a limited consideration of race, which the University of Texas did. But Texas kept the percentage approach in place as the primary means of admitting students. A secondary avenue, which considers race among many factors, was added, and is at issue in the Fisher case.
California has the oldest lasting ban on affirmative action, adopted by voters in November 1996 as Proposition 209.
- Richard P&#233;rez-Pe&#241;a 
 10:19 A.M. | Court Rules in Affirmative Action Case 
The Supreme Court issued a ruling on Monday in Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin, a case concerning affirmative action.
From SCOTUSblog:
The opinion by Kennedy. The Fifth Circuit is vacated and remanded. The holding is because the Fifth Circuit did not hold the university to the demanding burden of strict scrutiny articulated in Grutter and Bakke, its decision affiming the district court's grant of summary judgment was incorrect.
There is one dissent. It is 7-1. Ginsburg dissents alone. There are separate concurring opinions by Scalia and Thomas. Kagan was recused.
- The New York Times 
 9:32 A.M. | Explaining The Times's Coverage of the Decision 
We realize that people will be eager to know what the ruling means as soon as it comes out (and you can read the decision yourself when it is posted on the court's Web site). But we also want to point out that the immediate descriptions of any ruling may not be very meaningful.
For one thing, a ruling could be complicated, as were last year's health care ruling and the 2000 Bush v. Gore ruling, and not amenable to instant summarizing. The court could even announce one portion of a decision - especially on same-sex marriage, given the two different cases - before it releases another portion.
Dozens of Times journalists, in Washington, New York and around the country, are covering the ruling and the reaction to it by the public and those affected by it. At the center of the coverage is Adam Liptak, the Supreme Court reporter (and a lawyer) of The Times, who will be in court to hear the ruling.
We plan to explain the ruling the moment we feel comfortable with its basic meaning - which could be almost immediately. We promise not to bombard you with guesswork or unintelligible legal technicalities. The Times will also run blog posts from the legal experts at SCOTUSblog on our own site, as well as ask other outside experts to help readers understand the decision. Once the fundamentals of the ruling are clear, Times reporters and editors will be analyzing it in real time, on our live blog dedicated to the ruling and on stories appearing across our digital platforms. We will also post updates to Twitter on @thecaucus and @nytimes, and post selected reactions from readers.
We expect to have Mr. Liptak's initial story about any ruling by late morning or shortly after noon, not long after the court's session has ended. Whatever happens Thursday, we also expect at least one major ruling to come next week.
Thanks for being with us.
- The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 24, 2013

SECTION: US; politics

LENGTH: 4752 words

HEADLINE: Live Analysis of Supreme Court Decision on Affirmative Action

BYLINE: THE NEW YORK TIMES


HIGHLIGHT: The Supreme Court ruled on Thursday on Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin, a case concerning affirmative action. Times reporters and editors are analyzing the decision and its implications, as well as the public&#8217;s reaction to it. 

 BODY:
 The Supreme Court ruled Monday that lower courts did not apply a sufficiently high level of scrutiny to the University of Texas' use of race in admissions decisions, sending the case back to one of those lower courts to be reconsidered.
 1:48 P.M. | Four Questions for Lee Cheng 
 Lee Cheng is a co-founder and secretary of the Asian American Legal Foundation, which was established in 1994. He was the co-author of an amicus brief in Fisher v. the University of Texas at Austin, arguing against the university's affirmative-action program. 
 Q. How would you summarize the decision in a single sentence? 
 A. The expansion of the Grutter doctrine has been halted: the court ruled today that universities like the University of Texas cannot discriminate on the basis of race, no matter how well-intentioned, and that the means and effects of all race-based programs must be subjected to the highest standards of review by courts.
 Q. Did anything in in it - or in the justices' votes - surprise you? 
The court's decision in Fisher v. Texas was not surprising. It was the most likely decision possible among the various options - the type of Solomonic baby splitting that Supreme Court justices seem to love.
We were surprised by the size of the majority in this decision, and the absence of more concurrences and dissents. We did not
expect Justices Breyer or Sotomator to join the majority, but are glad that so many of the justices were willing to recognize that all race-based programs should be questioned and challenged to determine whether they are indeed sufficiently designed to and actually
achieve their purported societal benefits.
 Q. How broad of an effect do you think the ruling is likely to have? Will it affect admissions policies anywhere other than the University of Texas, and will it affect areas outside higher education? 
 A. The court ruled today that all race-based programs, whether in higher education or not, must be, more than ever, subjected to the highest level of judicial scrutiny. I can see challenges to programs across the country in higher and even K-12 education, and eventually in employment and contracting.
 Q. What's next for affirmative action? 
 A. While the use of race as one of many factors to consider continues to be permitted, as it was in Grutter, the court arguably enhanced the level of scrutiny for all programs using race as a consideration based on the means used and the effects of such programs. It's like the court is theoretically allowing race to be considered but also requiring accountability for all programs using race.
In terms of tangible effects, the decision likely means two things: (a) the expansion of the number and sophistication of programs
that use race in admissions, and (b) additional litigation challenging race-based programs across the country.
- The New York Times 
 1:02 P.M. | Four Questions for Desiree C. Boykin 
 Desiree C. Boykin is the interim general counsel assistant secretary of the United Negro College Fund. She is a co-author of a recent amicus brief to the Supreme Court on Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin, arguing for the university's affirmative-action program.

 Q. How would you summarize the decision in a single sentence? 
A. In requiring the lower Court to follow the standards set forth in Grutter, the Supreme Court has preserved its earlier holding that a
diverse learning environment is a compelling interest that benefits all students and our country as a whole.
 Q. Did anything in in it - or in the justices' votes - surprise you? 
 A. No. In remanding the case, the Court is requiring that its prior rulings in Grutter and Bakke are followed and that the appropriate burden of proof is applied.
 Q. How broad of an effect do you think the ruling is likely to have? Will it affect admissions policies anywhere other than the University of Texas, and will it affect areas outside higher education? 
 A. Any impact to admissions policies will not be known until after the lower court's review.
 Q. What's next for affirmative action? 
 A. We believe that the University of Texas at Austin's admissions policy is a carefully crafted policy that will ultimately be upheld by the Courts.
- The New York Times 
 12:50 P.M. | Four Questions for Roger Clegg 
 Roger Clegg is the president and general counsel of the Center for Equal Opportunity, a conservative organization. From 1982 to 1993, he held a number of positions at the U.S. Department of Justice and he argued three cases before the United States Supreme Court. 
 Q. How would you summarize the decision in a single sentence? 
 A. Strict means strict.
 Q. Did anything in in it - or in the justices' votes - surprise you? 
 A. That we had to wait so long for a decision that, while ultimately positive, is still quite limited and brief.
 Q. How broad of an effect do you think the ruling is likely to have? 
 A. The combination of the ruling and the run-up to the ruling - in which it has become clear how increasingly unpopular and discredited racial preferences in admissions are - will result in some serious soul-searching among university presidents on whether "diversity" is really worth the price of racial discrimination. At least, I hope so.
 Q. Will it affect admissions policies anywhere other than the University of Texas, and will it affect areas outside higher education? 
 A. Certainly the soul-searching I describe should take place at all universities that use racial preferences. It might cause for some corporate soul-searching, too, since unfortunately corporate America has bought into the diversity-via-discrimination approach in a big way.
 Q. What's next for affirmative action? 
Preferential treatment based on race, ethnicity, and sex - the sort of"affirmative action" that is objectionable as a policy and legal matter - will continue its steady march to the dustbin of history. And deservedly so.
- The New York Times 
 12:44 P.M. | Four Questions for Richard D. Kahlenberg 
 Richard D. Kahlenberg is a senior fellow at The Century Foundation. He is author of "The Remedy," a 1996 book about affirmative action, as well as a coauthor of the recent report "A Better Affirmative Action."

 A. By making it much harder for universities to employ racial preferences, the Supreme Court has paved the way for a new affirmative action based on economic disadvantage.

 A. I was surprised that the court sent the case back to the lower court and surprised that Justices Breyer and Sotomayor were willing to sign on to a tougher standard - that on the question of narrow tailoring "the university receives no deference," and the requirement that "judges must ultimately be satisfied that no workable race-neutral alternative would produce the educational benefits of diversity."

 A. The effect will be national in scope, influencing the admissions policies at both public and private colleges and universities across the country. In the past universities have relied heavily on racial preferences and given almost no consideration to economic disadvantage. By requiring universities to first pursue "race-neutral" alternatives like economic status, the Supreme Court could effectively flip the equation. If universities want racial diversity, they will first have to try to achieve it by using alternative means such as economic status.

 A. While the Supreme Court left the door open a crack for using race (in cases where "no workable race-neutral alternatives" are available) economic affirmative action will likely come to predominate in college admissions over time. In the 2007 Supreme Court striking down racial integration plans in Louisville and Seattle in 2007, Justice Kennedy described ways in which race could still be used, but virtually all school districts pursuing integration shifted to emphasizing socioeconomic status rather than race. The new higher standard is likely to discourage universities from using race and opening themselves up to litigation. If that occurs, the decision will be a boon to low income and working class students of all racial backgrounds who have to date been effectively shut out of selective colleges.

 12:13 P.M. | Four Questions for Sheryll Cashin 
 Sheryll Cashin is a law professor at Georgetown and former law clerk to Thurgood Marshall. Next year, she will publish a book entitled, "Place Not Race: Creating Opportunity for All After Affirmative Action." 
 Q. How would you summarize the decision in a single sentence? 
 A. After nearly a year of debate and anxiety on both sides of the question, the court in a 7 to 1 decision largely maintained the status quo, i.e. universities have a compelling interest in pursuing diversity but they cannot use rigid racial quotas.
 Q. Did anything in in it - or in the justices' votes - surprise you? 
 A. I was surprised that the court left intact its decision in Grutter (the Michigan affirmative case). Although Justice Kennedy dissented in that case, writing for the majority today he took Grutter and Bakke as givens. Justice Kennedy seems to have made his peace with Grutter in part by putting his gloss on it. He is very comfortable with the idea that universities have a compelling interest in the educational benefits of diversity. He reaffirmed that they even deserve deference on why diversity produces educational benefits. He made it clear, however, that any use of race must be narrowly tailored and that judges, not universities, get to decide what narrow tailoring means. His bottom line was this: when an affirmative action plan gets challenged in court, the court must be satisfied that there are "no workable race-neutral alternatives" to achieve the educational benefits of diversity.

 A. In the near term I think many universities are breathing a sigh of relief. I think universities will be reviewing their admissions plans carefully over the summer and watching to see what happens to the University of Texas's plan on remand. The decision is more important for U.T. than other universities; U.T. could lose on remand.
 Q. What's next for affirmative action? 
 A. There will always be another Abigail Fisher. Opponents in this case did not ask the court to overrule Grutter. There are four votes to overrule Grutter but Kennedy has indicated in this opinion that he is not inclined to do it. I think opponents of affirmative action will keep chipping away at it through litigation and in the political sphere, lobbying Republicans in state legislators to adopt bans. We are up to eight state bans, and this opinion may galvanize more political opposition. I also think university admissions offices will continue experimenting with race-neutral alternatives that help create racial and economic diversity in a less divisive way. Hopefully the anxiety about lawsuits will cause universities to revisit admissions policies that are exclusionary, like standardized tests and legacy admissions.
- The New York Times 
 11:57 A.M. | Decision Lands on a Busy Day at the White House 
White House officials in every administration like to brag about being able to multitask during days when the news hits them from all sides.
This is one of those days.
National security officials are chasing Edward Snowden, the National Security Agency leaker, across the globe. The immigration battle in the Senate is entering its final week. The president is preparing for a huge climate policy announcement on Tuesday. Oh, and the Supreme Court on Monday morning issued a ruling on affirmative action programs at the nation's colleges, the first of what could be landmark rulings in four cases this week that have broad implications for the nation.

And later Monday, White House officials are holding a briefing for reporters to preview the president's remarks on climate change. Mr. Obama is expected to announce his intention to propose new regulations limiting carbon dioxide emissions from existing power plants.
Meanwhile, the president's travel and protocol offices are waiting to see what happens with Mr. Mandela, who has been in a hospital for three weeks, battling a long-standing lung infection. On Sunday, South African officials said his condition had become critical.

For the moment, White House officials are just going to have to be flexible. Or, as Jay Carney, the president's current press secretary, said recently, "We can walk and chew gum at the same time."
- Michael D. Shear 
 11:36 A.M. | Four Questions for Richard Primus 
 Richard Primus is a professor specializing in constitutional law at the University of Michigan Law School. He is a former Rhodes Scholar and served as a clerk to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg. 
 Q. How would you summarize the decision in a single sentence? 
 A. The Michigan model of affirmative action - upheld by the court in 2003 - remains valid for now, and the court will watch universities closely to make sure they don't go an inch beyond it.
 Q. Did anything in in it - or in the justices' votes - surprise you?
 A. Many people predicted that a 5-to-4 conservative majority would use this case to eliminate affirmative action. Those predictions were probably based more on fear (from the left) and wishful thinking (from the right) than on careful consideration of what the center of this court - Justice Kennedy - has said in the past. The result in this case is perfectly Kennedyesque: universities may consider race to ensure diverse student bodies, but only if they really need to, and Justice Kennedy's court will be in charge of deciding whether they really need to.
What's remarkable is how broad a coalition agreed to handle the case in this moderate way. Sometime in the future, the ultimate question of the validity of race-based affirmative action may have to be confronted again. But for now, even most of the court's conservative justices declined to use this occasion to say that they believe affirmative action to be flatly unconstitutional.
 Q. How broad of an effect do you think the ruling is likely to have? Will it affect admissions policies anywhere other than the University of Texas, and will it affect areas outside higher education?
 A. The ruling will change little. It reaffirms the status quo, with emphasis on the court's own role as arbiter. After a lot of buildup and drama, this round ends with a whimper and not a bang.
 If we believed that the court was in the business of applying precedent scrupulously and cautiously, this shouldn't surprise us. The big story here is the gap between the public's expectation of big news and the quiet, technical resolution the court chose. For which there can be two explanations: Either the public has come to expect the court to act even more ideologically than it does, or else affirmative action touches a nerve raw enough that we expect it to produce fireworks. Or both.
 Q. What's next for affirmative action? 

A. There will be more rounds of argument about whether "race-neutral alternatives" can produce diversity. "Race-neutral" needs to be in quotation marks, because people have very different ideas about what counts as race-neutral. (Is class-based affirmative action race-neutral if it is intended to produce racial diversity?) Nobody can predict where those arguments will end up, and nobody knows what the court will look like when the issue comes back - which it eventually will. For now, though, this decision will change little about either what universities do in practice or how people more broadly talk about affirmative action. The conversation goes on with just a minor bump.
- The New York Times 
 11:21 A.M. | Bans on Racial Preferences Have Had Mixed Results 
Though Monday's decision will most likely have few immediate implications for affirmative action programs around the country, it may represent the start of a new wave of challenges to the use of race in admissions decisions.
The following states have already banned affirmative action, a move that blocks consideration of race or ethnicity in admission to state colleges: California, Washington, Florida, Michigan, Arizona, New Hampshire, Nebraska and Oklahoma.
In most states, the bans have been followed by an initial sharp drop in enrollment of black, Hispanic and Native American students. The states have responded with a range of policies intended to boost diversity through race-blind means.
But the results have been mixed, both racially and socioeconomically. The affected state universities vary widely in the racial mix of their state populations, their selectivity, their levels of support from state government and how aggressively they have pursued diversity programs.
- Richard P&#233;rez-Pe&#241;a 
 11:14 A.M. | Four Questions for Stuart Taylor 
 Stuart Taylor Jr. has covered the Supreme Court and other matters for National Journal, The New York Times, Newsweek, The American Lawyer and Legal Times. Last year, he and Richard Sander published "Mismatch: How Affirmative Action Hurts Students It's Intended to Help, and Why Universities Won't Admit It." 
 Q: How would you summarize the decision in a single sentence? 
 A. This is an extremely narrow decision reversing the lower court for giving too much credence to the "good faith" of the University of Texas in its use of race and for failing to consider race-neutral alternatives.
 Q. Did anything in in it - or in the justices' votes - surprise you? 
 A. Yes. It was widely expected to be a 5-to-3 decision (with Justice Kagan recused) cutting back on universities' ability to use racial preferences. Instead, Justice Kennedy's majority opinion did not change the law at all.
 Q. How broad of an effect do you think the ruling is likely to have? Will it affect admissions policies anywhere other than the University of Texas, and will it affect areas outside higher education? 
 A. The effect will be very narrow, and the lower court's options include reaffirming its support for the Texas racial-preference plan that the Supreme Court had agreed to review.[#x200b]
 Q. What's next for affirmative action?

 A. The Supreme Court will hear arguments this fall in another big case, Schuette v. Coalition to Defend Affirmative Action, involving a 2006 ballot measure amending the Michigan constitution to prohibit (among other things) racial preferences in state university admissions. The United States Court of Appeals for the 6th Circuit struck down that provision by a party-line vote, with eight Democratic appointees outvoting seven Republican appointees. The majority reasoned that it violated the Constitution's guarantee of equal protection of the laws for a state constitutional amendment to require equal treatment of all racial groups, because the ballot measure had made it harder for racial minorities than for other groups (such as alumni children) to win preferential treatment. Dissenters countered that "a state does not deny equal treatment by mandating it," in the words of Judge Jeffrey Sutton.

- The New York Times 
 10:51 A.M. | Court Calls for More Scrutiny 
The Supreme Court ruled Monday that lower courts did not apply a sufficiently high level of scrutiny to the University of Texas at Austin's use of race in admissions decisions, sending the case back to one of those lower courts to be reconsidered.
The decision will most likely have few immediate implications for affirmative action programs around the country, including in Texas. But it may represent the start of a new wave of challenges to the use of race in admissions decisions.
In a 7-to-1 decision, with Justice Anthony Kennedy writing the majority opinion, the court ruled that the lower court did not use a legal standard known as strict scrutiny to assess the university's program.
"Strict scrutiny," the opinion read, "does not permit a court to accept a school's assertion that its admissions process uses race in a permissible way without closely examining how the process works in practice."
Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg was the lone dissenter in the case, Fisher v. the University of Texas.
Read the decision.
- The New York Times 
 10:47 A.M. | On Affirmative Action, Focus Is on Public Schools 
All of the major rulings on affirmative action, from Bakke in 1978 to Hopwood in 1996 to Grutter and Gratz in 2003 to Fisher today, have involved public universities.
But legal experts say it is only a matter of time before similar challenges are filed against private colleges, as well - and they are likely to succeed.
Plaintiffs have challenged affirmative action as a violation of the 14th Amendment, whose equal protection clause bars discrimination by government, but not by private parties. But Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 prohibits discrimination by any entity that uses federal funds - which describes almost all colleges and universities.
Many private college administrators say they already operate under the assumption that the restrictions the Supreme Court has placed on public universities also apply to them.
- Richard P&#233;rez-Pe&#241;a 
 10:43 A.M. | Public Is Split Along Racial and Partisan Lines 
The public is deeply divided across racial and partisan lines on affirmative action, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll conducted early this month.
The poll found that more than half of Americans, 53 percent, favor affirmative action programs for minorities in hiring, promoting and college admissions, while 38 percent oppose them. (Other polls in the past that have asked about giving minorities "preference" have shown less support.)
Three-quarters of black respondents support such programs, but fewer than half of whites agree. And while support is at 75 percent among Democrats, it drops to 51 percent among independents and falls even further to just 37 percent among Republicans.
Among those who favor such programs, most say the main reason is to increase diversity, rather than to make up for discrimination.

- The New York Times 
 10:28 A.M. | Texas Has History on Affirmative Action 
Texas was one of the first states to have a ban on affirmative action, and though the prohibition was later overturned, it has had a lasting effect on higher education in that state, and an influence on the Fisher case.
In March 1996, in Hopwood v. Texas, the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals struck down affirmative action, in a case involving admission to the University of Texas Law School. The ruling held sway in the states of that circuit, Texas, Louisiana and Mississippi.
It was in response to that ruling that Texas adopted the practice of admitting all students in the top 10 percent of their high school classes to the state's universities, including the flagship at Austin.
But in 2003, in Grutter v. Bollinger, a case involving the University of Michigan, the Supreme Court overturned the Hopwood decision. That allowed state colleges in the Fifth Circuit to return to a limited consideration of race, which the University of Texas did. But Texas kept the percentage approach in place as the primary means of admitting students. A secondary avenue, which considers race among many factors, was added, and is at issue in the Fisher case.
California has the oldest lasting ban on affirmative action, adopted by voters in November 1996 as Proposition 209.
- Richard P&#233;rez-Pe&#241;a

The Supreme Court issued a ruling on Monday in Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin, a case concerning affirmative action.

The opinion by Kennedy. The Fifth Circuit is vacated and remanded. The holding is because the Fifth Circuit did not hold the university to the demanding burden of strict scrutiny articulated in Grutter and Bakke, its decision affiming the district court's grant of summary judgment was incorrect.
There is one dissent. It is 7-1. Ginsburg dissents alone. There are separate concurring opinions by Scalia and Thomas. Kagan was recused.

 9:32 A.M. | Explaining The Times's Coverage of the Decision 
We realize that people will be eager to know what the ruling means as soon as it comes out (and you can read the decision yourself when it is posted on the court's Web site). But we also want to point out that the immediate descriptions of any ruling may not be very meaningful.
For one thing, a ruling could be complicated, as were last year's health care ruling and the 2000 Bush v. Gore ruling, and not amenable to instant summarizing. The court could even announce one portion of a decision - especially on same-sex marriage, given the two different cases - before it releases another portion.
Dozens of Times journalists, in Washington, New York and around the country, are covering the ruling and the reaction to it by the public and those affected by it. At the center of the coverage is Adam Liptak, the Supreme Court reporter (and a lawyer) of The Times, who will be in court to hear the ruling.
We plan to explain the ruling the moment we feel comfortable with its basic meaning - which could be almost immediately. We promise not to bombard you with guesswork or unintelligible legal technicalities. The Times will also run blog posts from the legal experts at SCOTUSblog on our own site, as well as ask other outside experts to help readers understand the decision. Once the fundamentals of the ruling are clear, Times reporters and editors will be analyzing it in real time, on our live blog dedicated to the ruling and on stories appearing across our digital platforms. We will also post updates to Twitter on @thecaucus and @nytimes, and post selected reactions from readers.
We expect to have Mr. Liptak's initial story about any ruling by late morning or shortly after noon, not long after the court's session has ended. Whatever happens Thursday, we also expect at least one major ruling to come next week.
Thanks for being with us.

HEADLINE: Making Misconduct a Crime

BYLINE: PETER J. HENNING


HIGHLIGHT: A proposal in Britain to allow the prosecution of bank executives when they engage in reckless misconduct raises the question of whether the United States should consider a similar measure. 

 BODY:
A persistent criticism since the financial crisis hit has been the lack of any significant prosecutions of senior executives at the financial firms that received billions of dollars in taxpayer-financed bailouts. In Britain, the Parliamentary Commission on Banking Standards suggested adding a new law to allow the prosecution of British bank executives when they recklessly engage in misconduct that puts the bank and its customers at risk of severe losses.
It is an interesting question whether Congress should consider similar legislation to make it easier to hold financial executives criminally liable for decisions that can result in billions of dollars of losses, much of which may be borne by taxpayers as long as there are institutions considered "too big to fail." 
One reason given by the Justice Department for the absence of any significant prosecutions of corporate executives is the difficulty prosecutors face in proving an individual's specific intent to commit a crime. Lanny A. Breuer, the former head of the Justice Department's criminal division, offered that explanation in a PBS "Frontline" special entitled "The Untouchables" about the lack of financial crime prosecutions: "But when we cannot prove beyond a reasonable doubt that there was criminal intent, then we have a constitutional duty not to bring those cases."
This is especially problematic when chief executives and other officers may be well removed from the actual decisions that led to the losses. They can plausibly assert their ignorance about what actually happened. When authority is diffused through an organization, it can be almost impossible to hold anyone accountable.
The British proposal would obviate at least some of that difficulty by using a lower threshold to allow a conviction if the government proved that an executive recklessly engaged in misconduct. Under American law in general, recklessness is defined as consciously disregarding a substantial and unjustifiable risk of harm from conduct that is a gross deviation from what a reasonable person would do. A defense of "I didn't know" can be more easily overcome if the person should have been aware of what was happening but charged headlong into risky transactions.
There is nothing comparable to the British proposal in the United States to prosecute this type of financial misconduct by executives. At one time, the federal mail and wire fraud statutes were used against corporate leaders who breached the duty of honest services that involved conflicts of interest and other actions that put their own interests ahead of those of an employer.
Among those prosecuted under this theory was Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former chief executive of Enron. The Supreme Court used his case to limit honest services fraud prosecutions to only instances of bribery and kickbacks, not more general corporate mismanagement that caused harm to the enterprise through dishonesty. Mr. Skilling's sentence was reduced by 10 years last week in exchange for his dropping any further appeals in his case.
With the honest services fraud theory off the table, few options are available to pursue corporate executives for misconduct that does not require proving the higher level of intent bemoaned by the Justice Department.
Civil enforcement actions by the Securities and Exchange Commission can be brought for reckless violations, and some fraud violations require only proof of negligence. But even that lower threshold has proved to be a challenge in cases arising from the financial crisis.
For example, a jury found in favor of Bruce Bent Sr. for his statements about the stability of the Primary Reserve Fund, a money-market fund whose meltdown during the financial crisis unnerved investors, even though the S.E.C. had to prove only negligence. Similarly, a former Citigroup middle manager was cleared of securities fraud charges under the same standard for his role in selling a collateralized debt obligation tied to subprime mortgages that lost much of its value within months of its issuance. The S.E.C. has a trial scheduled next month against Fabrice Tourre, formerly of Goldman Sachs, for his role in peddling a faulty security that will present a significant challenge in whether it can prove he was reckless.
Adopting a statute along the lines of the parliamentary commission's recommendation might have some modest deterrent effect on financial executives, who could fear that they might be made an example by prosecutors seeking to hold someone accountable for a bank's failure. Whether that would make them overly timid in how they manage the bank's operations by avoiding any risk of failure is one plausible response.
Requiring proof of recklessness would not necessarily mean that more executives would be prosecuted successfully for the type of decisions that led to the financial crisis. The recommendation for the new crime in Britain candidly admits that "all concerned should be under no illusions about the difficulties of securing a conviction for such a new offense." The parliamentary commission also said that this new authority could be used only when there are substantial costs imposed on taxpayers or the threat of serious harm to customers, a fairly small class of cases.
In the end, the frustration expressed over the lack of any prominent criminal prosecutions of bankers that captured the public's imagination like the case against Mr. Skilling may be less about the standard for proving a violation than finding proof to link executives to decisions that were clearly criminal. For all the talk about how the financial crisis must have entailed fraud, much of the conduct during that period seemed to involve a headlong rush into risky transactions without understanding the consequences. Whether that was misconduct or just stupidity is not an easy question to answer.
The British proposal for a new crime of reckless mismanagement would give prosecutors another tool to use in the next financial crisis. A lower standard for proving intent might encourage the government to take on tough cases because it would be harder for financial executives to offer up their ignorance or good faith about the details of risky transactions as a shield against being held responsible.
But a new criminal offense would not have any effect on the financial crisis of a few years ago because the Constitution prevents applying a new law to old conduct.

        
After Financial Crisis, Prosecutors Navigate Tricky Waters
        
Ex-TV Cop's New Role: Confidential Informant

HEADLINE: Lessons of the Great Recession: How the Safety Net Performed

BYLINE: JARED BERNSTEIN


HIGHLIGHT: As markets failed, programs to help those hardest hit had uneven results, but showed their value in keeping poverty from escalating, an economist writes. 

 BODY:
Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. 
Though the economy is clearly improving, we've yet to fully escape the gravitation pull of the great recession. The job market remains weak, and wages and middle-class incomes remain stagnant.
But we're on the mend, and the likelihood of slipping back into recession is low. So it's none too soon to begin asking the question: what have we learned about economic policy in this crash that should inform our thinking for the next downturn? Lord (Keynes) knows, there's been a lot of policy - fiscal, monetary and financial - to evaluate. 
Let's start with the safety net since it's a fixture of advanced economies and serves the critical function of catching (or not) the most economically vulnerable when the market fails. What follows is a brief overview of a many-faceted topic, but there's solid evidence that key parts of the safety net performed well - probably better than you thought.
Before I get to the evidence, a word about context. First, as suggested above, there's another recession lurking out there somewhere, so let's learn what worked and what didn't.
Second, and this is particularly important in today's political economy, too many policy makers devalue the safety net. In Representative Paul Ryan's terminology, it's a "hammock." For Ronald Reagan, it was a feckless weapon in the "failed" war on poverty (though to his credit, he extended a wage subsidy for low-wage workers that has become a highly effective anti-poverty tool). For many of today's conservatives, the increased use of a safety-net program is proof that there's something wrong with the user, not the underlying economy.
But while people do abuse safety nets - and not just poor people (think bank bailouts and special tax treatment of multinational corporations) - I want to see receipt of unemployment insurance, the rolls of the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (food stamps), and so on go up in recessions. In fact, their failure to do so would be a sign that something's very wrong, like an air bag that failed to deploy in a crash.
The figure below tracks three programs, two which responded quite elastically to the downturn, and one - Temporary Assistance for Needy Families, or T.A.N.F. - which did not. (I'll get to why unemployment insurance has gone down while SNAP remained elevated in a moment.)
There are two reasons that T.A.N.F. was so unresponsive. First, welfare reform in the mid-1990s significantly increased its work requirements, which worked well then, as the policy change interacted with historically strong demand for low-wage labor. Since then, and especially in the great recession, the low-wage job market has been much less welcoming.
Second, T.A.N.F. was "block granted," meaning states receive a fixed amount that is largely insensitive to recessions (my colleague Liz Schott has noted some minor wrinkles) and inflation. Since the block grant began, the real value of T.A.N.F. funds is down 30 percent. Now, consider this: it is a fixture of conservative policy on poverty to apply this same block grant strategy to food stamps and Medicaid. The numbers and the chart above show this to be a recipe for inelastic response to recession, or, more plainly, a great way to cut some big holes in the safety net.
A useful way to show the effectiveness of the safety net in the downturn is to look at poverty rates before and after counting the value of its benefits. The figure below gets close to that for child poverty. As officially (and incorrectly) measured, poverty rates reflect the impact of only a minority of safety-net benefits. For example, they include unemployment insurance but not SNAP.
The official rate for children goes up over the recession, from 18 percent to 22 percent, but once you include the full force of safety-net (and Recovery Act) measures that kicked in, it holds steady at about 15 percent. Though child poverty rates even under the alternative measure are still too high, this figure provides strong evidence of the effectiveness of the American safety net in the worst recession since the Depression.
Finally, because the recession is receding, shouldn't the SNAP rolls be coming down as well? The answer gets back to the points made above regarding the ongoing weakness in the job market. In a recent paper, the economists Peter Ganong and Jeffrey Liebman asked the following question: based on the historical relationship between SNAP rolls and unemployment, where would we expect SNAP roles to be?
The answer: pretty much where they are. Though their growth has decelerated, SNAP rolls remain elevated because their function remains critical in what's still a tough job market for low-income households. Unemployment insurance rolls, on the other hand, have come down in part because they serve a broader swath of the population, and in part because extended benefits have been prematurely cut back.
I'm not suggesting we celebrate elevated SNAP rolls. Their height is evidence that the economy remains too weak for eligible households to afford adequate nutrition and that our current economic policy agenda isn't doing enough to offset that weakness. But the fact is that markets fail, and when they do, income and food supports must rise to protect the most economically vulnerable families.
So let's get this straight: the poor and their advocates were not the ones who tanked the economy. Nor should they be on the defensive when the safety net expands to offset some of the damage. The right question at such times is thus not why the SNAP rolls are so high. It's whether SNAP, unemployment insurance, T.A.N.F. et al are expanding adequately to meet the needs of the poor.
